title: Boris Johnson pays comical tribute to John Bercow in speaker’s last PMQs
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

A heated final PMQs before the general election got off to a light-hearted start as Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn each paid joke-filled tribute to outgoing speaker John Bercow.

It was the last time the leaders will trade barbs in the weekly session before Parliament is dissolved next Tuesday ahead of the vote on December 12.

Mr Bercow announced he will stand down tomorrow and the PM drew laughs from the chamber by jibing he had ‘done more than anyone since Stephen Hawking to stretch time in this particular session’.

‘As we come to the end of what must be the longest retirement since Frank Sinatra, Mr Speaker, I’m sure the whole House will want to join me in thanking you and hoping that you enjoy in your retirement the soothing medicament that you have so often prescribed for the rest of us,’ he added.

Labour leader Mr Corbyn similarly quipped: ‘I hope you will indulge me for one moment while I say a word about you – I’m sure you will.’

Mr Johnson drew laughs with his comic tribute to Mr Bercow (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Mr Bercow will stand down tomorrow (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the speaker ‘stood up for Parliament when it had to be stood up for’ (Picture: PA)

It wasn’t all jokes and gentle ribbing though, as both men thanked Mr Bercow for being a great servant in the Commons, especially taking up the fight on behalf of backbenchers.

Mr Corbyn said: ‘I want to thank you Mr Speaker for the way that you’ve used your speakership in the decade-long tenure you’ve had.

‘You’ve done so much to reform this House of Commons and our democracy is the stronger for the way that you’ve done it.’

He added that Mr Bercow had ‘stood up for Parliament when it had to be stood up for’ helped take it away from being ‘a gentlemen’s club’ that happens to be in a palace to being ‘a genuine democratic institution’.

Independent MP and former minister Ken Clarke also paid his own tribute.

He said: ‘During your decade, there have been unprecedented attempts really to try to, at times, increase the power of the Executive at the expense of this Parliament, and you have been very formidable in maintaining the duty of government to be accountable to this House. I trust your successor will try to live up to your very considerable achievement.’

MPs applauded Mr Clarke, who is stepping down as an MP, as Mr Bercow hailed him as ‘one of the most popular and respected politicians in our country’.

The session ended with Mr Bercow thanking ministers for their kind words before he welled up as he thanked his wife and three children ‘for the support, stoicism and fortitude they have displayed through thick and thin over the last decade’.

‘I’ll never forget it and I’ll always be grateful for it,’ he added.
